bibl.title: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thomas M. England, November 27, 1941

div1.p: Hench discusses his yellow fever research and sends England a copy of his “Conquerors of Yellow Fever” article. He mentions England's participation in the experiments.

div1.head: Letter from Philip Showalter Hench to Thomas M. England, November 27, 1941
div1.opener:
New address.
Major T. M England
Medical Administrative Corps
Surgeons office
5th Corp Ave
Columbus Ohio
November 27, 1941
Capt. Thomas M. England
1715 East Long Street
Columbus, Ohio
My dear Captain England:
div1.p:
I have been interested in the story of the
conquest of yellow fever and have been doing some study
of it the past four or five years. I have had the pleasure
of corresponding with many of those concerned and have
visited Kissinger, Moran, General Kean, Miss Agramonte,
Walter Reed's daughter and others. I have just published
an article on Conquerors of Yellow Fever; you are mentioned
in this article and I am sending you a few copies by separ-
ate post. If you want more, I'd be glad to send as many
as you wish.

I should deem it a privilege to correspond with
you. It has been a deep source of satisfaction to me to be
able in a very small way to honor you who helped to conquer
yellow fever.
div1.closer: Very sincerely, P. S. Hench, M. D. psh:ds
